data.title: Culinary Adventure
data.text:
Not a very big restaurant, but lively.  I love the idea of sharing small plates.  Trouble is, when there is 4 of you, often times things come out in 3's.  They recommend that you order about 3 dishes per person which we did, but we ended up having too much food.  A cool thing that Sarma does is come around with a tray of prepared chef's specials that you can get on the spot. 
 My favorite dish we ordered was the Brisket Shawarma.  I know the Seven Layer Hummus gets favorable reviews, however, it is hard to distinguish which flavor hummus you are eating.
Overall, great dining experience.

data.title: Delicious, always new and interesting
data.text: Open a few years now, this restaurant aways offers something new and interesting on the menu. And we have never been unhappy with the food or the cocktails. Definitely worth a visit if you like Mediterranean/Turkish style cuisine.

data.title: Awesome meals
data.text: My wife and I were finally able to make it to Sarma. Parking fills up really fast and we ended up walking about 1/4 mi to restaurant. Very noisy and busy place but quickly learned why. Many dishes are served at the table and after trying 8 or 9 different small plates, we were sold! Extremely tasty and made with the freshest ingredients. Wonderful experience.

data.title: Sharing sensational food
data.text: With no reservation we tried our luck on a busy Friday night. Thanks to a no show we were seated as a party of 5 at a table for 4. No worries as we were all sharing the delicious mezes. Our favorites were shawarma, sliders, broccoli, Brussels sprouts, ceviche and the 7 layers of hummus just to name a few. Every bite was so full of flavor, texture and crunch. No more room for dessert but we will keep that in mind for next time.

data.title: Amazing to very good
data.text: We have eaten at Sarma 4 times and it is clearly an excellent restaurant.  The drinks are always outstanding in every way.  Make sure you consult with the generally very helpful staff to pick the right drink for you.  We usually arrive promptly at 5 pm and take a seat at the bar and sign up for the first come first serve high top tables.  We have always gotten a table. Sarma has small plates that range from interesting and amazing to very good.  I would say the first two times we were really impressed with dishes ranging from fried chicken to cauliflower to variations on falafel.  This is an outstanding restaurant that is worth a visit.  However, order carefully because some dishes are just ok-in general, though-outstanding.

data.title: Meze dim sum
data.text: Small plates to share. We had about 10 between the four of us. Each was wonderful. (That was too much food, but so delicious we ate every bit). It bills itself as Turkish food, though I had nothing quite like it in Turkey. The come around with premade meze to offer you (dim sum style), which honestly I think is unnecessary. Nothing bad to say.

data.title: Absolute Somerville gem - I love this place!
data.text:
We came here for a friend's birthday -- and after a long day at work, the consensus sour (rum, smoked maple, something and egg white) was perfect - not too strong, just flavorful and delicious.   One person in our party is allergic to half the world, and the chef dry-erased a menu blacking out the items she couldn't have and writing in those that could be modified - she loved it - and loved the food.  

The other 2 of us - pretty much ordered 3 items between us, thinking we were being good, until the specials came by and we added the magnificent deviled eggs, and the tuna tartare.  A-MAZ-ING!    The dishes we ordered and highly recommend (seriously, there wasn't a mediocre dish to be had) - was the lamb kofte sliders, pork belly biscuits, sambusek (I think I spelled that right -- basically cured beef and cheese in pastry, with cucumber yogurt), cauliflower fatteh, brisket schwarma (yum) and apricot glazed scallops.   

We certainly couldn't finish the last few dishes, but my head was greedy for more, while my stomach said "OK, enough already"..  Everything was fantastic and our waiter was a great help with recommendations.   

Go and Enjoy!  (And dress code is nice casual -- people wore hoodies and jeans, and others wore dresses.  I had a sparkly shirt, blazer and jeans and wasn't over or under dressed)

data.title: A delightful find!
data.text:
The husband and I are generally not fans of small plates. (Ends up too pricey and unsatisfying, all too often.)
But Sara was a great treat. 
The flavors are Turkish-influenced and intrigue the palate. In addition to the menu, the chef creates a dim sum style offering of "chef's whims" each evening. The one we chose was fried chicken with intriguing sauces. The venison-wrapped dates were also excellent. The celery root tzatziki was a delight, and the phyllo borek a treat. Our one disappointment was the brisket shawarma -- didn't taste much of brisket. 
But we were delighted and will definitely be back!

data.title: Maybe the Best Restaurant in Boston?
data.text:
My wife and I eat out several times a week and enjoy great restaurants.  We do this in our home town of New York, but we also do it when we travel.  I've been to Sarma twice.  It is one of my two favorite restaurants in the Boston metropolitan area. 

If anybody tells you this isn't some of the best Mediterranean food that they ever tasted, then they are wrong....that SIMPLE!

Sarma's dishes are tapas size portions of some of the most interesting interpretations of Middle Eastern/Mediterranean dishes.  The staff encourage sharing.  The waitstaff knows the dishes and the ingredients.  The menu as a whole represents a common theme while the dishes themselves provide an amazing contrast of flavors.

The cocktails are also inventive, but if you order a traditional cocktail, they get that right as well.

I only have good things to say about this restaurant !

data.title: Wow! Do not miss this one!
data.text: This cozy restaurant serves wonderful Mediterranean inspired small plates that will meet any persons exacting standards.  They are creative, well-flavored and have a Marvell vegetarian selection.  Be sure to get a reservation, though walking in is always a possibility.

data.title: See Michaels Review of Sept 25, 2016
data.text: His review is pretty dead on for me aside from the references to Oleana, a restaurant I've not been to, yet.

data.title: Good food but........
data.text:
We had supper here recently on a Fri. evening, early.  Let me preface this review by saying that Oleana is one of our favorite Boston restaurants.  Sarma is a sister to Oleana.  The food is similar, small plates with middle eastern flavors.  Prices are reasonable.  We enjoyed the food, but the atmosphere and location were not worth the trip to Somerville.  Oleana is a cozy comfortable atmosphere located in a classic Cambridge neighborhood.  Sarma on the other hand has hard wooden chairs for seating (very uncomfortable) and is located in a classic Somerville neighborhood.  Difficult parking.  
The service at Parma is more relaxed, but the idea of bringing extra dinner choices on trays, to the table, during supper is a bad idea.  The atmosphere here is already fairly noisy with many wait staff moving throughout.  I am not a big fan of meal interruptions by wait staff, who are hawking add-ons for supper.  Kind of like eating at a middle eastern bazaar, only in Somerville.  
So, all in all, though we enjoyed the food we will continue our love of Oleana and ignore her Sarma sister.

data.title: Amazing Turkish meze restraurant - you won't be disappointed!
data.text:
You'll need reservations, and this place books up quickly.   Go in a group - four people (or more, but reservations might be challenging for a larger group).  The restaurant features meze, which means little plates - think tapas if you're not familiar with middle east cuisine.   The idea is to order 2-3 plates per person, share among the table, and they leave the menu with you in case you need to order more.
Standing outside the restaurant, you already get a wonderful heady perfume of scents; this is only a tease as to what you'll experience.  The dishes are wide and varied, beautifully presented, and best of all - delicious.  Wonderful spices, interesting combinations, delightful "bites" of flavor  The menu is lengthy, and they also have specials, which they bring around and you can choose - or not - and again, the specials are also meze.  
Unlike most restaurants, their wine list - which is small - features most wines both by the glass and by the bottle.  The waiters and waitresses have a good knowledge of the wines, which is important as some come from Italy, some from the middle east, some from southern France.  Again, these are wines you might find in a meze restaurant.
After your meal - which will be so wonderful that at some point you'll realize you're soon to become uncomfortably full, so follow their guidelines (start out at two dishes per person, and then add as you go along) - and don't miss their desert menu.  
There were a just a few desserts - and a wide offering of "toppings" for either the yogurt or the ice cream, I think it was - but also a bewildering array of aperitifs or digestivs, dessert wines and exotic coffees.   Again, foods you would expect from the area.
We will definitely go back again; alas, we probably won't remember everything we ordered this time because frankly we'd like to try ALL their dishes.

data.title: Tapas style Turkish food with a fully stocked bar
data.text:
The place is turkish fusion and the food feels like a Turkish version of a tapas restaurant. The food, all the stuff that we ordered was very good and the staff kept bringing out specials on a platter for the guests to pick. Beef short ribs were the pick of the food, though the gyros and all other food was spectacular. Portions are a medium sized which gives the place a tapas lie feel.

Lovely cocktails on the menu and the last one on the list is a whisky based cocktail with molasses, very nice.

Place can be a bit crowded and noisy, but that does add to the atmosphere.

data.title: INTERESTING AMERICAN TAPAS wEMENU
data.text:
We had a verly lovely time at this casual restaurant.  The tapas in general are good and very nicely presented.  The short rib was a bit tough and the lamb was very good.
Do try the corncakes; I think the best of all of the 8 dishes that we tasted.  Do remember to make a reservation.
We did have an excelent waiter.  The best!

data.title: Small plate restaurant.
data.text: This is a casual but lively restaurant. It features small plates and you order 2 or 3 a person. They also walk around with plates of house specials like a Dim sum restaurant. Most dishes were excellent especially the lamb sliders and the corn cake plate. The bread was also superb. It is fun and even if a few of the dishes were only good the overall experience is delicious.

data.title: One of Bostons Best.... Is in Somerville
data.text: A top restaurant in the Boston area.  While Somerville has some of the best bars and Reston, Sarma is further an off the "beat" location.  Magnificent aand somewhat unique dining experience.  Not your typical "tapas" / small plates.  Flavors are euphoric.  Cocktails are damn good too.  Take an Uber....so you can have a few and because parking isn't very easy.

data.title: A fun place to eat with friends
data.text: Tapas like servings (memes) with middle eastern cuisine. Each entry was tasty with beautiful presentation. Lively crowd and a nice bar. Service was good. Parking can be challenging. Make reservations in advance

data.title: Delicious!
data.text: Small plates, lot of choices (vegetarian & not). Everything we had was delicious. Love the atmosphere, highly recommend it.

data.title: Creative food in a cool environemnt
data.text: roaming small plates with unusual spice combination, vaguely eastern Mediterranean? Often very crowded but wife and I can usually grab seats at the bar, have a nice cocktail or two, watch the kitchen and try to resist the small plates that are walked around the place. A bit on the spendy side as most tapas tend to be, but very satisfying
